div.p: SEVERALL PAPERS From His Excellency Sr. Thomas Fairfax, AND The ARMIE under his Command, delivered to the Commi≈ø≈øioners of Parliament and City at Alisbury, July 23. 1647.
OCCASIONED By a late Petition and Engagement of ≈øome Citizens, Commanders, Officers, and Souldiers of the Trained Bands and Auxiliaries &c.

p.hi: Being the la≈øt and mo≈øt de≈øperate De≈øigne again≈øt the Kingdome and Army. With a Copy of the Engagement.

div.p: ALSO, A Proclamation from his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, again≈øt the entertaining of Cavaliers in the ARMIE.

body.p: By the appointment of his Excellency Sr. THOMAS FAIRFAX and his Councell of Warre.

div.p: London, Printed for George Whittington, at the Blew Anchor in Cornhill, neare the Royall Exchange, 1647.

VVE received this inclo≈øed paper the la≈øt night, from the hands of a very well affected Citizen, it was delivered him by an Officer of the City Militia who being invited to meet ≈øome Citizens at Skinners hall upon Wedne≈øday la≈øt, with divers others to ≈øigne the ≈øame, and offering to di≈øpute again≈øt the matter of it, to ≈øhew how dangerous and illegall it was, was ≈øilenc't and told that it was not to be di≈øputed, but to be ≈øigned and joyned in, there being diver≈øe Cittizens and others at the ≈øame place for that purpo≈øe, which when he under≈øtood, he tooke this printed Copy away with him,

By the contents of which when you read it you will ea≈øily perceive what it tends to, and how de≈øperate and dangerous it is to the hazzard of the whole Kingdom, and to fru≈øtrate all tho≈øe indeavours of the Parl. the army and Kingdome for an happy ≈øettlement, and likewi≈øe to precipitate all into a new and bloody war, we cannot therefore but acquaint you that we look on this as a bu≈øine≈ø≈øe ≈øet on foot by the malice of ≈øome de≈øperate minded men, this being their la≈øt Engine for the putting all into confu≈øion, when they could not accompli≈øh their wicked ends by other meanes. To this have all ≈øecret li≈øtings tended, and we wi≈øh that the needle≈ø≈øe and ≈øuperfluous Li≈øting of Auxilaries and connivance at the continuance of the Reformadoes about the Cities of London, and We≈øtmin≈øter, have not had the ≈øame aime, and by this wee hope it will appeare that our iealou≈øies and feares of ≈øome ≈øuch de≈øperate de≈øignes to be harched in and about the City, (con≈øidering the temper of men there) have not bin groundle≈ø≈øe, nor our de≈øires to draw neere the City of London with the Army to di≈øapoint and breake all ≈øuch plots, and to free the Parliament from the violence of them have not bin without ju≈øt cau≈øe, and wee de≈øire all indifferent men to judg whether our withdrawing from the City in obedience to the Parliaments command was for their and the Kingdomes ≈øecurity or not: we wonder that divers men did calumniate that our marching ≈øo neare the City, and put ≈øo bad Repre≈øentations upon it, as that it tended to force the Parliament, or to plunder the City ≈øeeing our doing ≈øo, was to breake that blacke de≈øigne which now begins to ≈øhew it ≈øelfe in its colours,
whereas indeed our con≈øciences witnes with us, that our aymes were cleare & ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ne≈øt tending to re≈øtore the Parliament into its ju≈øt liberty, which was much abated in the eyes of all the Kingdome, and no doubt by the Authors and ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ntrivers of this new Covenant and engagement; ≈øome whereof have been ≈øo farre from a≈ø≈øi≈øting to put the Reformadoes & other dangerous per≈øons out of the Lines that now they are called to joyne in this con≈øpiracy: we intreate you to give the Parl. a full Repre≈øentation of the≈øe things, which that you may do; we have ≈øent you the Papers, together with ≈øuch informations as may give them an opportunity to di≈øcover the bottome of this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, we were marching from London (when we received this Information) in obedience to the Parliament, and to give the City more content, & to ≈øtop the mouthes of ≈ølanderers; But if ≈øuch De≈øignes, ≈øo di≈øtructive to the Parliament, and the worke in hand be ≈øuffered to go on, or that the Parliament be interrupted in the freedome of their debates and proceedings as we heare, within the≈øe few dayes they were, by tho≈øe that are invited to partake in this Con≈øideracy: we begg it of the Parliament, as they tender their own ≈øafety, the Peace of the Kingdome, and preventing of a ≈øecond Warre, as they would not have the Kingdome loo≈øe the fruite and benefit of all the blood and trea≈øure that hath been ≈øpent in this cau≈øe, that they would not ≈øuffer their freedome and liberty to be indangered by ≈øuch de≈øignes as the≈øe, they having an Army which by the Ble≈ø≈øing of God, in ≈øpight of all that theirs and the Kingdomes enemies can do, will ≈øtand and fall with them, and be found faithfull and obedient to them in all things, and as ready to relieve Ireland, when the Peace and rights of this Kingdome are ≈øeried: We write not this to de≈øire the Parliament to invite us to march up to them, we care not how great a di≈øtance we are from London, if it be the Parliaments plea≈øure, and con≈øi≈øts with their ≈øecurity, and the breaking of tho≈øe combinations which are hatcht in the Bowels of the City, we are ha≈øtening our Propo≈øalls which are for the generall ≈øettlement, and which (we are confident) will ≈øatisfie all that love truth and peace: But we ≈øee plainly, we neede more to intend ≈øecurity then have cau≈øe to expect to bring things to an happy i≈ø≈øue by Treaty while ≈øuch de≈øignes are on foote: We pray you therefore that the Parliament would ≈øpeedily and throughly inquire into, and break the≈øe De≈øignes wherein as in all things, el≈øe we ≈øhall be ready to ≈øerve them as they ≈øhall judge it needfull, and when they ≈øhall command us.

closer.signed: By the appointment of his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, and his Councell of Warre. Signed, Iohn Ru≈øhworth, Secr.

div.p: BY a Printed Paper come to our hands this day (a Coppie whereof you receive herewith) we ≈øtill find, and cleerly and evidently perceive that ≈øome evill Spirits within the City of London, maliciou≈øly di≈øaffected to the Peace of this Kingdome, do ≈øecretly and wickedly endeavour, to bring about that mi≈øchiefe upon the Kingdome, which we have ≈øo much feared, and by all our ≈øeverall addre≈ø≈øes unto you ≈øought to prevent; which indeede are of that dangerous con≈øequence as we can expect no other i≈ø≈øue from, then the unavoydable engaging the Kingdome in a ≈øecond Warre, if not timely and effectually prevented by your wi≈ødome and diligence. Wee mu≈øt further ob≈øerve unto you, that whatoever de≈øign is intended in the for≈ø≈øad Paper, is contrary to the Authority of Parliament, and indirect oppo≈øition to the proceedings of the Army (which the 2. Hou≈øes have owned as theirs, and approved of their fidelity by committing the forces of the Kingdome of England, Dominion of Wales, and I≈ølands of Garne≈øey and Ier≈øey, under the Generals care and Command) and therefore cannot be effected, but by force of Armes again≈øt the Parliament and their Armies, which in probability may involve the whole Kingdome in blood; but mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily begin within your own Bowels, and draw the Seate and mi≈øery of Warre upon you and your City.

Al≈øo we de≈øire you would con≈øider, whether we have not ju≈øt cau≈øe to ≈øu≈øpect that an evill party lurkes within the City ready to di≈øtemper it, and the whole Kingdome upon every occa≈øion, and whether it be probable ≈øuch per≈øons de≈øire a happy Clo≈øe between the King and the Parliament, (at lea≈øt ≈øuch as will be for the Kingdomes good) when they take upon them the boldne≈ø≈øe to make new offers to His Maj. with ≈øolemn engagements to make good the ≈øame during the time that the Parliament had given us leave to make tender of, and treate with their Commi≈ø≈øioners about tho≈øe things which tend to a generall ≈øettlement. And therefore we cannot but de≈øire, that you would take a ≈øpeedy cour≈øe timely to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe this great evill, and to prevent all of this nature for the future, and by making ≈øome of tho≈øe examples who have been active to carry on this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe: We have not had time to enquire into particulars, out ≈øhall give you onely one in≈øtance of a meeting at Skinners-Hall, concerning this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, where ≈øome per≈øons have been very active, (the names of ≈øome of whom we have given to your Commi≈ø≈øioners) and al≈øo the names of other Citizens who will te≈øtifie their carriage there.

La≈øtly, we cannot but de≈øire you to concur ‚Ä¢ with us in our de≈øires to the Parliament, to put the Militia into the hands of tho≈øe that had it before; without which we can have no a≈ø≈øurance that the City will be free from de≈øignes of this nature, nor can we expect to ≈øee a happy Clo≈øe.

The humble Petition of the Citizens, Commanders, Officers, and Souldiers of the Trained Bands and Auxilaries, the young men, and Apprentices of the Cities of London, and We≈øtmin≈øter, Sea Commanders, Seamen and Watermen, together with divers other Commanders, Officers, and Souldiers within the Line of Communication, and Pari≈øhes, mentioned in the Weekly Bill of Mortality.
div.p: THat your petitioners (taking into ≈øerious con≈øideration how Religion, his Maie≈øties honour and ≈øafetie, the priviledges of Parliament and liberties of the Subiects, are at pre≈øent greatly endangered, and like to be de≈øtroyed, and al≈øo ≈øadly weighing with our ≈øelves, what meanes might likely prove the mo≈øt effectuall, to procure a firme, and la≈øting peace, without a further effu≈øion of Chri≈øtian Engli≈øh bloud, have therefore entred into a ≈øolemne engagement, which is hereunto annexed, and do humbly and earne≈øtly de≈øire, that this whole City may joyne together by all lawfull and po≈ø≈øible meanes, as one man, in harty endeavours for his Maje≈øties pre≈øent comming up to his two hou≈øes of Parliament, with honour, ≈øafety, and freedom, (and that without the neerer approach of the Army) there to confirme ≈øuch things as he hath granted in his Me≈ø≈øage of the 12th. of May la≈øt, in an≈øwer to the Propo≈øitions of both Kingdoms, and that by a per≈øonall Treaty with his two hou≈øes of parliament, & the Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Kingdom of Scotland, ≈øuch things as yet are in difference may be ≈øpeedily iettled, and a firme, and la≈øting peace e≈øtabli≈øhed; all which we de≈øire may be pre≈øented to both hou≈øes of parliament from this honourable A≈ø≈øembly,

div.head: A Solemne ingagement, of the Citizens, Commanders Officers, and ≈øouldiers of the Trainbands, & Auxiliaries, the yong men, and prentices of the Cities of London and We≈øtmin≈øter Sea Comanders, Seamen, and Watermen, together with divers others the Comanders, Officers and ≈øouldiers, within the lines of Communication, and Pari≈øhes mentioned in the Weekly Bill of Mortality.
div.p: WHereas wee have entered into a ≈øolemne League and Covenant, for Reformation and defence of Religion, the honour and hapyne≈ø≈øe of the King, and the peace and ≈øafety of the the 3 Kingdomes, of England, Scotland, and Ireland; All which wee doe eminently perceive not only to be indangered, but ready to be de≈øtroyed, we do therefore in pur≈øuance of our ≈øaid Covenant, Oath of Allegiance, oath of every freeman of the Cities of London, and We≈øtmin≈øter, and prote≈øtation ≈øolemnly ingage our ≈øelves, and vow unto Almighty God, that we wil to the utmo≈øt of our power cordially indeavour that his Maie≈øty may ≈øpeedily come to his two hou≈øes of Parliament, with honour, ≈øafety, and freedom, (and that without the neerer approach of the Army) there to confirme ≈øuch things as hee hath granted in his Me≈ø≈øage of the 12 of May la≈øt, in an≈øwer to the Propo≈øitions of both Kingdomes, and that by a per≈øonall Treaty with his two hou≈øes of Parliament, and the Com. of the Kingdome of Soctland, ≈øuch things as are yet in difference may be ≈øpeedily ≈øetled, & a firm and la≈øting peace e≈øtabli≈øhed, for the effecting hereof we doe prote≈øt and reobleige our ≈øelves as in the pre≈øence of God the ≈øearcher of all hearts, with our lives and fortunes, to indeavour what in us lies to pre≈øerve and defend his Maje≈øties Royall Per≈øon, and authority, the priviledges of parliament, and liberty of the Subject in their full & con≈øtant freedom, the Cities of London and We≈øtmin≈øter Lines of Communication, and Pari≈øhes mentioned in the Weekely Bill of Mortality, and all others that ≈øhall adhere with us, to the ≈øaid Covenant, and oath of Allegiance, oath of every freeman of London, and We≈øtmin≈øter, and Prote≈øtation, Nor ≈øhall Wee by any meanes admit ≈øuffer or endure any neutrality in this Common cau≈øe of God, the King, and Kingdome as we do expect the Ble≈ø≈øing of Almighty God, whole help we crave, & wholly devolve our ≈øelves upon in this our undertaking.

I Doe hereby require the chiefe Officer pre≈øent with every Troop and Company, to make ≈øtrict inquiry what Cavaliers haue been li≈øted and entertained in their Troopes or Companies, ≈øince the Mu≈øter preceding the la≈øt Mu≈øter; And that all ≈øuch chiefe Officers ≈øhall pre≈øently upon ≈øuch enquiry as before, put forth of their Troopes or Companies of ≈øuch Cavaliers as they ≈øhall find in their troopes or Companies from ≈øuch Musters (as before) And before they receive any pay upon this la≈øt Muster, they ≈øhall expunge the Names of all ≈øuch Cavaliers out of their Mu≈øter Rolls, as they ≈øhall have put out of their Troopes or Companies. And if it ≈øhall hereafter appeare (that any chiefe Officer pre≈øent with their Troope or Company) ≈øhall neglect to put forth, or ca≈øhiere ≈øuch Cavaliers in manner as before, or receive any for the time to come upon proof thereof made, he ≈øhall be liable to a Councell of Warre, and be accordingly proceeded again≈øt.
